questions.text: An 85-year-old man is brought to the emergency room after being found on the floor in his home. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 101/min, respirations are 22/min, and blood pressure is 188/94 mmHg. The patient appears conscious, but does not demonstrate spontaneous movement of the extremities and is unable to respond to voice or painful stimuli. The patient is able to blink and eye movements are restricted to the vertical plane. Magnetic resonance angiogram will most likely reveal ischemia of which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
This patient's inability to move the extremities, loss of horizontal eye movements with preserved consciousness, and loss of mouth, tongue, and facial movements, is consistent with locked-in syndrome (LIS), due to the occlusion of the basilar artery. The most vulnerable territory associated with this condition lies at the paramedian base of the pons.  

Clinical features consistent with locked-in syndrome include:  

  • Quadriplegia and inability to speak or swallow due to the involvement of corticospinal and corticobulbar tracts 
  • Preserved consciousness due to the sparing of the reticular formation 
  • Loss of horizontal eye movement due to the involvement of ocular cranial nerve nuclei and paramedian pontine reticular formation 
  • Voluntary blinking and vertical eye movements remain intact, which are controlled in the rostral portion of the brainstem  

Option Analysis

❌ Posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Posterior inferior cerebellar artery occlusion results in lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome characterized by vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, bulbar weakness, and Horner syndrome.  
❌ Anterior spinal artery:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome, which typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Anterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: Lateral pontine syndrome occurs secondary to occlusion of anterior inferior cerebellar artery (AICA). Patients typically present with signs of a lower motor neuron facial nerve lesion, vertigo/nystagmus, ipsilateral cerebellar signs, loss of pain/temperature sensation on the ipsilateral face and contralateral body, ipsilateral sensorineural loss, and Horner syndrome.  
✅ Basilar artery:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Posterior cerebral artery infarction typically results in contralateral hemianopia due to infarction of the visual cortex. The macula is often spared due to contralateral circulation from the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A 78-year-old woman presents to the emergency department with sudden onset vertigo, gait disturbance, and a stabbing pain on the right side of her face. The patient does not have fever, weight loss, chest pain, palpitations, or shortness of breath. Past medical history includes type 2 diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and hyperlipidemia. Temperature is 37.7°C (99.8°F), pulse is 83/min, respirations are 18/min, and blood pressure is 156/90 mmHg. The patient falls to the right when asked to sit without support. Neurological exam is significant for partial ptosis and miosis of the right eye, nystagmus, and reduced pain and temperature sensation on the right face and left body. The patient’s voice sounds hoarse and she does not gag with oral tongue blade insertion. Hearing is intact bilaterally. Which of the following anatomic structures is the most likely site pathology given this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
This patient’s neurological findings are consistent with lateral medullary (Wallenberg) syndrome. This condition involves reduced blood supply to some (or all) of the following structures of the dorsolateral medulla including the inferior cerebellar peduncle, vestibular nuclei, fibers or nuclei of nerve IX or X, spinal nucleus and tract of V, spinothalamic tract, and sympathetic pathway. The dorsolateral medulla receives its blood supply from the posterior inferior cerebellar artery.  

Clinical features of lateral medullary syndrome include:
 
  • Dysphagia, hoarseness, diminished gag reflex, and hiccups due to the involvement of nucleus ambiguus (CN IX, X, XI)
  • Vomiting, vertigo and nystagmus, attributable to vestibular nuclei involvement
  • Diminished pain and temperature sensation of the contralateral body and ipsilateral face due to involvement of lateral spinothalamic tract and spinal trigeminal nucleus 
  • Ipsilateral Horner (miosis, ptosis, and anhidrosis) due to involvement of sympathetic fibers innervating the head and neck 
  • Ipsilateral ataxia and dysmetria due to the involvement of inferior cerebellar peduncle 

Option Analysis

✅ Lateral medulla  :
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Posterolateral thalamus  :
Incorrect: A pure sensory stroke often occurs secondary to malperfusion of the ventral posterolateral and/or ventral posteromedial nucleus of the thalamus–a key cerebral structure that relays sensory information regarding proprioception, pain, pressure, and temperature to the primary somatosensory cortex. Affected individuals present with numbness of the face and body (contralateral to the affected side of the thalamus).  
❌ Medial medulla:
Incorrect: Infarction of the paramedian branches of the anterior spinal artery results in medial medullary syndrome. This condition typically presents with contralateral hemiparesis (lateral corticospinal tract), decreased contralateral proprioception (medial lemniscus), and ipsilateral tongue paralysis (hypoglossal nucleus).  
❌ Basal pons:
Incorrect: Hypoperfusion of the basal pons results from occlusion of penetrating arteries, leading to the development of dysarthria (clumsy hand syndrome). Affected individuals present with facial weakness, dysphagia, dysarthria, and weakness of the hand ipsilateral to the lesion. Sensory deficits are absent in patients with this condition.  
❌ Parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Diminished perfusion of the parietal lobe results from occlusion of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) and/or middle cerebral artery (MCA). Malperfusion of the parietal lobe may result in numbness; however, a stroke of the nondominant hemisphere manifests with contralateral neglect, while infarction of the dominant side manifests with aphasia, finger agnosia, agraphia, or dyscalculia.

questions.text: A 78-year-old right-handed man is brought to the emergency department following sudden-onset weakness in his right arm and inability to speak for twenty four hours. The patient’s daughter states she initially became concerned when he dropped his cup of coffee while walking to the kitchen table last night. The daughter states he has had a similar episode in the past that resolved spontaneously. He has a history of hypertension, for which he takes lisinopril. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 158/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and visibly frustrated by not being able to speak. Physical examination reveals 2/5 strength in the right upper extremity and 4/5 strength in the right lower extremity. He follows written and verbal commands but is unable to speak or write. MRI of the head demonstrates ischemic changes in the cerebral territory supplied by the left middle cerebral artery. Which of the following histopathological findings are most likely to be observed in this patient’s brain at the present time?

choices.text: Eosinophilic neuronal cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei

questions.solution:
This patient suffered from an ischemic stroke, as suggested by his focal neurologic deficits and corroborating MRI findings. In the hours, days, and weeks following an ischemic stroke, there are several histopathological changes that occur in the area of infarction. The first histopathological changes appear after 12 to 24 hours, although irreversible damage actually begins after five minutes of hypoxia. The following describes the histopathological timeline following an ischemic stroke:

  •  12-24 hours: Neurons appear red with eosinophilic cytoplasms and loss of Nissl substance, which is a large granular body found inside neurons, and pyknotic nuclei. Red neurons are indicative of irreversible damage.  
  •  24-72 hours: Necrosis and neutrophilic infiltration. 
  •  3-5 days: Infiltration of microglial cells (macrophages of the brain) which phagocytose damaged neurons.  
  •  1-2 weeks: Reactive astrocytes migrate to the site of infection, resulting in gliosis. Vascular proliferation (formation of new capillaries) also occurs around the area of necrosis.  
  •  > 2 weeks: Scar tissue forms to fill the infarcted space. 
Macroscopically, after one week to one month, microglial cells that contain hydrolytic enzymes digest the dead neuronal cells into a soft, purulent substance of dead immune cells--termed liquefactive necrosis. After approximately one month, the brain tissue is replaced by a cystic cavity surrounded by a glial scar.  

Option Analysis

❌ Astrocytic and vascular proliferation:
Incorrect: Astrocytic and vascular proliferation occurs one to two weeks following an ischemic stroke, not within 24-hours.
❌ Glial scar formation:
Incorrect: After an ischemic stroke, astrocytic proliferation results in the formation of a closely connected firm meshwork, termed a gliotic scar. Formation of this glial scar occurs after two weeks, when astrocytes are able to enter the ischemic, damaged region of the brain following vascular proliferation.
❌ Neutrophilic and microglial infiltration:
Incorrect: Neutrophils move into the ischemic, damaged area of the brain in the first 48-72 hours following onset of symptoms. During this time, liquefactive necrosis occurs due to neutrophil lysosomal enzyme release.
✅ Eosinophilic neuronal cytoplasm and pyknotic nuclei:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ No observable histopathological changes:
Incorrect: Under a microscope, the first histopathological changes following an ischemic stroke appear after 12 to 24 hours, although irreversible damage actually begins after five minutes of hypoxia.

A 69-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of loss of sensation in the right upper and right lower extremity of one hour duration. The patient was working in his basement when he began losing feeling in his right arm and leg throughout the morning. He became more concerned when he developed a headache with associated non-bilious non-bloody vomiting. The patient has a history of untreated hypertension and hyperlipidemia. He does not take any medications. He drinks 6-8 beers on the weekends and has a 30-pack year smoking history. Current temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 91/min, and blood pressure is 225/108 mmHg. Physical examination demonstrates an obese, ill appearing male with 2/5 weakness in the right upper and right lower extremities. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick of the right upper and lower extremities. A non-contrast CT of the head is shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Which of the following risk factors is the most likely cause of this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH), which often occurs secondary to long-standing untreated hypertension. The imaging findings demonstrate a hemorrhage within the  internal capsule, as seen by the hyperdensity (blood) in the left basal ganglia. Internal capsule hemorrhage may present with dysarthria, contralateral hemiparesis, sensory deficit, or both. Neurologic symptoms typically increase gradually over minutes to hours as the hemorrhage expands. In contrast, the neurologic findings of a large vessel embolic stroke are often maximal at onset. If the hemorrhage becomes large, signs of increased intracranial pressure may arise including headache, vomiting, and a decreased level of consciousness.

Hypertension is the primary risk factor for IPH, and hypertension-induced degenerative changes in small, perforating arteries increase the likelihood of rupture through the formation of Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms. These small aneurysms, undetectable by angiography, supply deep grey matter structures including the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, and cerebellum. 

Option Analysis

❌ Alcohol use:
Incorrect: High alcohol intake is associated with an increased risk of intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, is not the most significant risk factor.
✅ Hypertension:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Hyperlipidemia:
Incorrect: Hyperlipidemia is associated with an increased risk of intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, uncontrolled hypertension is a more significant risk factor.
❌ Obesity:
Incorrect: Obesity is associated with various adverse outcomes; however, it is not a direct risk factor in the development of this patient’s intraparenchymal hemorrhage.
❌ Tobacco use:
Incorrect: Smoking is associated with various adverse outcomes, and it also increases the risk of developing an intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, it is not the most significant risk factor.

A 79-year-old man is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset numbness affecting the right upper and lower extremity as well as right sided visual deficit. The patient was playing golf with his son when he suddenly lost the ability to sense holding the golf club with his right hand. He was then unable to get into the golf cart due to “blurry vision.” The patient has a history of poorly controlled hypertension. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 188/104 mmHg. The patient is alert and oriented. Sensation is decreased in the right arm and leg. Strength testing is intact throughout. A noncontrast head CT is demonstrated below:

 

 Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following visual deficits is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with hemisensory loss, associated visual deficits, and a noncontrast head CT demonstrating a left occipital lobe infarct. Given these findings, he likely suffered a left posterior cerebral artery stroke, resulting in right sided homonymous hemianopia.

Homonymous hemianopia refers to a loss of vision in either the left or right halves of the visual fields of both eyes. In the setting of stroke to the posterior cerebral artery, the vision lost reflects the side contralateral to the posterior cerebral artery affected. Although these patients suffer partial vision loss, macular sparing occurs, since the portion of the occipital lobe regulating this function receives dual blood supply from both the posterior cerebral artery as well as the middle cerebral artery.  

Option Analysis

❌ :
Incorrect: Non-homonymous bitemporal hemianopia often occurs due to a large pituitary adenoma compressing the optic chiasm, not a stroke of the left occipital lobe.
❌ :
Incorrect: Damage to the right temporal lobe (containing the Meyer loop) can result in superior left homonymous quadrantanopia, or “pie-in-the-sky” visual disturbances.
❌ :
Incorrect: Damage to the right parietal lobe can manifest with contralateral inferior homonymous quadrantanopia, or “pie-on-the-floor” visual disorder. These lesions may be caused by vascular occlusion of the middle cerebral artery.
❌ :
Incorrect: Left homonymous hemianopia with macular sparing can be seen in patients with occlusion of the right posterior cerebral artery. Macular sparing results from a dual blood supply to the visual cortex.
✅ :
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 62-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset left-sided weakness for the past two hours. She does not have chest pain, shortness of breath, or lower extremity pain. Past medical history includes self-resolved “recurrent infections'' while growing up in India. She immigrated to the United States in her twenties and was informed she has a cardiac murmur by several physicians. She does not smoke cigarettes, drink alcohol, or use illicit drugs. Temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is irregularly irregular at 121/min, and blood pressure is 108/68 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. Physical examination demonstrates 2/5 weakness and sensory loss in the left upper extremity and left lower extremity. Cardiac auscultation demonstrates a low pitched-diastolic rumbling murmur appreciated at the apex. There is no warmth, swelling, or erythema of the lower extremities bilaterally. Which of the following is the most likely anatomic source of this patient’s clinical condition?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs of a large vessel occlusion and sudden onset stroke in the setting of atrial fibrillation -- consistent with an embolic source. This patient’s history and murmur raises concern for rheumatic fever and subsequent mitral stenosis, respectively. In conjunction, these findings reflect an embolic source that most likely originated in the left atrium.

Ischemic and hemorrhagic comprise the two major types of strokes, with the majority of strokes being  ischemic in nature. Ischemic strokes are broadly defined as any stroke that arises from decreased blood flow to the brain and are further sub-classified into thrombotic, embolic, and hypoxic strokes.

  •  Embolic strokes occur when a cerebral blood vessel becomes occluded by an embolus, or a blood clot originating in a different anatomic region of the body. If the clot arises from the heart, it is called a cardioembolism, and these often occur in the left atrium in the setting of atrial fibrillation. Other causes of cardioembolic strokes include infective endocarditis and a left ventricular thrombus following myocardial infarction. Regardless, emboli from one of these sources can dislodge, travel to blood vessels supplying the brain, occlude them, and induce symptoms of a stroke.  
  •  Thrombotic strokes occur when a blood clot forms secondary to a ruptured atherosclerotic plaque. These thrombi can form anywhere atherosclerosis develops but particularly in the large cerebral blood vessels such as the middle cerebral artery, areas of vessel bifurcation, and the lenticulostriate arteries that supply the striatum and internal capsule. When strokes occur in these deep brain structures, they are termed lacunar strokes.
  • Hypoxic strokes, aka hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, or global cerebral ischemia, develop secondary to systemic hypoperfusion or hypoxia. This type of stroke commonly occurs during cardiac arrest, shock states, or during invasive procedures with significant blood loss. The pattern of injury observed with this type of stroke often includes watershed infarctions, since the areas of the brain most susceptible to ischemic injury exist at the border of blood supply between two separate cerebral arteries. The three primary watershed areas include the vascular territories between the anterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries,the posterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries, and the external and internal branches of the middle cerebral arteries.
 

Option Analysis

❌ Popliteal vein:
Incorrect: The popliteal vein is often implicated in patients with a deep vein thrombosis and subsequent pulmonary embolism. In very rare cases, the clot can travel to the systemic circulation via a patent foramen ovale in the heart. This patient has no evidence of deep vein thrombosis or a murmur characteristic of a patent foramen ovale.
❌ Femoral vein:
Incorrect: The femoral vein is implicated in patients with a deep vein thrombosis of the lower extremities. In very rare cases, the clot can travel to the systemic circulation via a patent foramen ovale in the heart.
✅ Left atrium:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Left ventricle:
Incorrect: The left ventricle can be a source of a thrombus, especially in patients with prior myocardial infarction. Dead, immobile cardiac tissue augments hemostasis and subsequent thrombus formation. This patient does not have a history or presentation concerning for acute or previous myocardial infarction.
❌ Pulmonary artery:
Incorrect: In patients with a pulmonary embolism (PE), an embolus from the lower extremities typically travels via the venous system into the pulmonary artery via the inferior vena cava. Patients with a PE typically present with pleuritic chest pain, shortness of breath, and hypoxia.

questions.text:
An 82-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of sudden onset left-sided weakness and lethargy. The patient lives at home with her son, who found the patient lethargic and unable to move the left side of her body. The son states over the past year, the patient has been forgetting names of common people as well as losing her abilities to perform activities of daily living.  She recently became lost in the parking lot of a grocery store she has been shopping at for decades. She has no past medical history. Her temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min and regular, and blood pressure is 171/94 mmHg. The patient appears somnolent but is arousable to voice and pain. Physical examination reveals marked weakness of the left upper and left lower extremity with associated decreased sensation in the left arm and leg. The patient’s eyes are currently deviated towards the right. A noncontrast CT of the head is shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following best describes the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical presentation?

choices.text: Arterial occlusion via medial hypertrophy and lipid admixed with fibrinoid material
Arterial-venous connections without an intervening capillary network
Embolic occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery
Rupture of arterial outpouchings at branch points within the circle of Willis
Smooth muscle degeneration with amyloid fibril deposition

questions.solution:
Cerebral amyloid angiopathy (CAA) refers to a condition where amyloid peptides, similar to those found in Alzheimer disease, deposit in the walls of medium and small-sized cerebral blood vessels. Amyloid deposition weakens blood vessel walls making them more prone to rupture and bleeding. Initially, amyloid fibrils deposit within the outer basement membrane, but they later accumulate in the media, resulting in degeneration of smooth muscle cells.

CAA-associated hemorrhages occur in the lobes of the cerebral cortex (lobar hemorrhages), which helps to distinguish them from hypertensive ICH, which more commonly affects the putamen, thalamus, and pons. Large lobar hemorrhages can cause hemiplegia and depressed consciousness, whereas smaller lobar hemorrhages result in focal deficits, seizure, or headache. 

Option Analysis

❌ Arterial occlusion via medial hypertrophy and lipid admixed with fibrinoid material:
Incorrect: Hypertensive vasculopathy occurs in the setting of chronic, uncontrolled hypertension. Intracerebral hemorrhage associated with hypertension is typically located in the deep brain structures (e.g., putamen, thalamus, and pons), as opposed to this patient’s lobar hemorrhage. While this patient is hypertensive, her clinical history of dementia makes another diagnosis more likely.
❌ Arterial-venous connections without an intervening capillary network:
Incorrect: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) can result in intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, they are more commonly seen in children and young adults. This older patient with a history consistent with dementia developed her intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to another pathophysiology.
❌ Embolic occlusion of the right middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: Embolic strokes typically occur in the setting of atrial fibrillation, in which a thrombus forms, dislodges, and occludes a cerebral artery. This patient has a regular heart rate, making atrial fibrillation unlikely.
❌ Rupture of arterial outpouchings at branch points within the circle of Willis:
Incorrect: A ruptured berry aneurysm presents with severe, sudden onset headache, seizures, and meningismus. Additionally, noncontrast head CT typically shows hyperdense fluid (blood) in the subarachnoid space.
✅ Smooth muscle degeneration with amyloid fibril deposition:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is scheduled to undergo an aortobifemoral bypass due to severe aortoiliac occlusive disease. Additional medical history includes hypertension, as well as a 45-pack-year smoking history. During the operation, the patient sustains significant blood loss and requires transfusion of 5 units of packed red blood cells. After the surgery, the surgeon and care staff note neurological deficits. Subsequent spinal MRI reveals infarction of the ventral segment of the spinal cord at the T4-5 level. Which of the following associated clinical findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?

choices.text: Hemiplegia and loss of pain/temperature sensation below the lesion
Ipsilateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation
Loss of motor function and vibratory sensation below the lesion
Quadriplegia and inability to speak with preserved consciousness

questions.solution:
At the confluence of the two vertebral arteries, two small branches arise and fuse to form a single anterior spinal artery that courses along the midline of the ventral surface of the spinal cord. This artery supplies the medial structures of the medulla in the brainstem, as well as the anterior two thirds of the spinal cord housing the corticospinal tract and spinothalamic tract. Ischemia in this territory often occurs during trauma or aortic surgery, resulting in anterior spinal cord syndrome.

In anterior spinal cord syndrome, MRI may show prominent high T2 signals with hyperintensities in the anterior aspect at affected spinal levels. Clinically, this results in contralateral paralysis below the level of the lesion, as well contralateral loss of pain and temperature due to associated damage to the corticospinal and spinothalamic tracts. Pressure, vibration, fine touch, and proprioception are spared, since these regions are supplied by the posterior spinal artery.



Option Analysis

❌ Contralateral hemiparesis and hemineglect:
Incorrect: A right middle cerebral artery stroke would cause left-sided weakness and hemineglect. This patient presents with anterior spinal cord infarction following a vascular surgery. 
✅ Hemiplegia and loss of pain/temperature sensation below the lesion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Ipsilateral hemiplegia and contralateral loss of sensation:
Incorrect: Spinal cord hemisection, aka Brown-Séquard syndrome, results in weakness or paralysis (hemiparaplegia) on one side of the body, with loss of sensation (hemianesthesia) on the opposite side.
❌ Loss of motor function and vibratory sensation below the lesion:
Incorrect: Posterior cord syndrome involves posterior columns with extension into the posterior horns. This syndrome manifests with loss of vibration and position sensation below the affected level.
❌ Quadriplegia and inability to speak with preserved consciousness:
Incorrect: A stroke affecting the basilar artery, specifically the pontine arteries, results in locked-in syndrome.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presents to the emergency department for evaluation following a 30-minute episode of left hand weakness. During the episode, the patient was unable to pick anything up with his left hand. He was able to lift his arm during the incident. He denies any difficulty with ambulation or speaking during the episode. The patient has a past medical history of uncontrolled hypertension and type 2 diabetes mellitus. He has a 20-pack-year history of smoking cigarettes. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 101/min and irregularly irregular, and blood pressure is 196/98 mmHg. The patient’s pulse oximetry is 99% on room air. He is alert and oriented, with fluent, clear speech. Motor strength is normal in all extremities, and there are no focal deficits appreciated. Non-contrast CT-brain does not demonstrate an acute intracranial process. CT angiogram of the head and neck demonstrates diffuse calcific atherosclerosis. Without appropriate medical treatment, which of the following adverse events is this patient most likely to sustain?
questions.solution:
This patient presents to the emergency department with resolved neurological deficits; he likely suffered a transient ischemic attack (TIA). TIAs result from a regional reduction in blood flow (i.e. ischemia) to the brain, causing transient neurologic deficits. Recognition of TIAs remains paramount, as 20% of these patients will go on to develop a full blown ischemic stroke in the hours to days following resolution of the neurologic deficits. Absence of infarcts on CT or MRI can help to confirm the diagnosis.

A TIA is managed via calculation of the risk of suffering a subsequent stroke by taking into account the patient’s age, blood pressure, clinical findings, duration of the TIA, and presence of associated risk factors. If the individual is deemed high risk, further hospitalization for advanced testing is appropriate. In addition, risk factor modification is appropriate for all patients with TIA, including blood pressure reduction, statins, antiplatelet therapy, lifestyle modification, and smoking cessation.

Option Analysis

✅ Cerebral ischemia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Subdural hemorrhage:
Incorrect: This patient’s recent transient ischemic attack (TIA) puts him at an elevated risk for a stroke in the coming days and weeks without appropriate medical management. Subdural hemorrhages more commonly occur due to associated blunt head trauma.
❌ Pulmonary embolism:
Incorrect: Pulmonary emboli are more common in patients with risk factors included in the Wells score--recent surgery, history of malignancy, hypoxia, or signs of a DVT.
❌ Seizure:
Incorrect: This patient had a transient ischemic attack (TIA), which places him at risk for a future stroke without appropriate medical management.
❌ Subarachnoid hemorrhage:
Incorrect: This patient likely had a transient ischemic attack (TIA), which is defined as a brief episode of neurological dysfunction caused by loss of blood flow and ischemia in the brain, spinal cord, or retina but without cellular death or infarction. Although this patient is at risk for hemorrhagic stroke (from hypertension), his recent TIA puts him at increased risk of a future ischemic event in the brain.

questions.text:
A 74-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of weakness and sensation disturbance in the left upper and left lower extremity for three hours. The patient was gardening, when she noticed she could no longer firmly grasp her trowel with her left hand. The patient became more concerned when she developed a diffuse headache shortly thereafter. Her daughter called emergency medical services after the patient became somnolent. The patient has a history of uncontrolled hypertension. Current temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 81/min and regular, and blood pressure is 201/104 mmHg. On initial evaluation, the patient is difficult to rouse. Physical examination demonstrates 2/5 weakness in her left upper and left lower extremity. There is decreased sensation to light touch and pinprick on the left side. A non-contrast CT of the head is shown below:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following best describes the underlying pathophysiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Large vessel occlusion due to cardiogenic emboli
Rupture of microaneurysms in weakened arterial walls

questions.solution:
This patient presents with an intraparenchymal hemorrhage (IPH), which often occurs secondary to long-standing untreated hypertension and subsequent formation of Charcot-Bouchard aneurysms. The imaging findings demonstrate a hemorrhage within the internal capsule, as seen by the hyperdensity (blood) in the right basal ganglia. Internal capsule hemorrhage may present with dysarthria, contralateral hemiparesis, sensory deficit, or both. Neurologic symptoms typically increase gradually over minutes to hours as the hemorrhage expands. If the hemorrhage becomes large, signs of increased intracranial pressure may arise including headache, vomiting, and a decreased level of consciousness.

Hypertension is the primary risk factor for IPH, and hypertension-induced degenerative changes in small, perforating arteries increase the likelihood of rupture through the formation of Charcot–Bouchard aneurysms. These small aneurysms, undetectable by angiography, supply deep grey matter structures including the basal ganglia, thalamus, brainstem, and cerebellum. Hypertension forms these aneurysms by inducing the proliferation of arteriolar smooth muscle, followed by apoptosis of smooth muscle cells and subsequent collagen deposition. Blood vessels with high collagen deposition cannot accommodate high blood pressures, since collagen has no contractile capabilities and is mechanically brittle. Ultimately, these high pressures cause the weak portions of the vessel wall to dilate and eventually burst.  

Option Analysis

❌ Inherited arteriovenous malformation:
Incorrect: Arteriovenous malformations (AVMs) can result in intraparenchymal hemorrhage; however, AVMs are the most likely precipitant in children and young adults. This older patient with a history of chronic, uncontrolled hypertension developed an intracerebral hemorrhage secondary to a different mechanism.
❌ Large vessel occlusion due to cardiogenic emboli :
Incorrect: Embolic strokes typically occur in the setting of atrial fibrillation, where a thrombus forms, dislodges, and occludes a cerebral artery. This patient has a regular heart rate, making atrial fibrillation unlikely. 
❌ Ruptured berry aneurysm:
Incorrect: A ruptured berry aneurysm manifestes with a subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH). Clinical findings of SAH include a severe, sudden onset headache that reaches maximal intensity within seconds to minutes, seizures, and meningismus. Additionally, noncontrast head CT demonstrates hyperdense fluid in the subarachnoid space, not the brain parenchyma.
❌ Rupture of middle meningeal artery:
Incorrect: Trauma to the middle meningeal artery may cause an epidural hematoma. Patients with epidural hematomas present with loss of consciousness following head trauma, with a lucid interval followed by progressive decline in mental status. Head imaging typically reveals a biconvex, hyperdense lesion.
✅ Rupture of microaneurysms in weakened arterial walls:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 66-year-old man comes to the emergency department for evaluation of sensory disturbance to the right half of his body. The patient was gardening when he suddenly developed right arm and leg numbness. He does not have weakness, urinary incontinence, or loss of vision. His past medical history includes hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and a 25 pack year smoking history. His temperature is 37°C (98.6°F), pulse is 92/min, and blood pressure is 178/98 mmHg. The patient reports 50% sensation to light touch of the right upper extremity and right lower extremity when compared to 100% sensation to light touch in the left upper and left lower extremity. Strength testing is intact throughout. Noncontrast head CT shows no abnormalities. This patient's clinical presentation reflects pathology to which of the following vascular structures?
questions.solution:
This patient with uncontrolled hypertension presents for evaluation of right-sided numbness and absent motor deficits -- suggesting a stroke of the thalamus, supplied by the lenticulostriate arteries. Acutely, these strokes are difficult to visualize on CT-imaging, and clinical suspicion should guide the physician towards advanced imaging via MRI.

Strokes of the basal ganglia, also called lacunar strokes are most commonly caused by ischemia of the lenticulostriate arteries -- a collection of small perforating arteries supplying the basal ganglia and arising from the anterior circle of Willis. After a lacunar stroke, the damaged brain tissue develops fluid-filled cysts, which look like little lakes (“lacunae”).

Lacunar strokes are most commonly initiated by atherosclerosis and arteriosclerosis from untreated hypertension, diabetes, and smoking. These conditions result in a type of arteriosclerosis called hyaline arteriolosclerosis where the arteriole walls fill with protein, reducing the size of the lumen, and causing ischemia to downstream tissue. Symptoms of lacunar strokes can vary based on anatomic location, as seen in the chart below.



Option Analysis

❌ Middle cerebral artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the middle cerebral artery (MCA) is characterized by contralateral motor and/or sensorimotor deficits, with the upper limbs being more affected than the lower limbs. If the dominant lobe is affected, the patient may demonstrate aphasia, whereas if the non-dominant lobe is affected, the patient may demonstrate hemineglect.
✅ Lenticulostriate arteries:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Anterior cerebral artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the anterior cerebral artery (ACA) is characterized by contralateral motor and/or sensorimotor deficits, with the lower limbs being more affected than the upper limbs. Patients often present with concomitant urinary incontinence, limb apraxia, and emotional disturbance.
❌ Basilar artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the basilar artery has a range of clinical presentations; some patients may present with vertebrobasilar insufficiency (e.g., vertigo, drop attacks, tinnitus), whereas others may present with locked-in syndrome (e.g. loss of movement of the extremities) if the pons is affected.
❌ Posterior inferior cerebellar artery:
Incorrect: An ischemic stroke of the posterior inferior cerebellar artery artery results in Wallenberg syndrome, which is characterized by ipsilateral Horner syndrome, dysphagia, hemiataxia, and contralateral sensory disturbances.

questions.text: A 77-year-old right-handed woman is brought to the emergency department for evaluation of increasing confusion and altered mental status. The patient has a history of transient ischemic attack last year without residual deficits, as well as hypertension, hyperlipidemia, and diabetes mellitus. Vital signs are within normal limits. The patient is alert and oriented to self and place only. When asked to write her name, the patient is unable to do so. Non-contrast CT-brain is performed, which demonstrates an acute  infarct in the inferior left parietal lobe. Which of the following associated clinical findings is most likely to be observed in this patient?
questions.solution:
This elderly patient with multiple risk factors for acute stroke is found to have an acute infarct of the inferior left parietal lobe in the region of the angular gyrus. If the dominant parietal hemisphere is affected, Gerstmann syndrome develops, which is characterized by a tetrad of symptoms (known as the four A’s), including:

  •  Finger agnosia refers to the patient unable to recognize different fingers on their own or another person’s hands. 
  •  Agraphia, or inability to write. 
  •  Alexia, or inability to read.
  •  Acalculia, or inability to do simple calculations. 

If the non-dominant parietal hemisphere is affected, hemispatial neglect syndrome occurs, wherein agnosia, or reduced awareness of the contralateral side of the body, ensues.


Option Analysis

✅ Acalculia and finger agnosia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Emotional lability and aggressive behavior:
Incorrect: Emotional lability and aggressive behavior are associated with damage to the prefrontal cortex (e.g., trauma, frontotemporal dementia) not the posterior parietal lobe. 
❌ Homonymous hemianopsia:
Incorrect: Homonymous hemianopia occurs with lesions affecting the occipital lobe, not the parietal lobe.
❌ Expressive aphasia:
Incorrect: The Broca speech area is located in the inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere (left in this patient, based on her handedness). When damaged, the result is Broca aphasia, also known as motor aphasia, due to the inability to express thoughts in a meaningful manner, while comprehension remains intact.
❌ Upper visual quadrantanopia:
Incorrect: A lesion to the inferior bank of the calcarine sulcus will cause upper quadrantanopia, not a lesion to the inferior parietal lobe.

questions.text:
A 22-year-old man is brought into the emergency department by emergency medical services after being found face down on the sidewalk. The patient has a temperature of 36°C (96.8°F), pulse of 62/min and regular, blood pressure of 102/72 mmHg and respiratory rate of 7/min, and O2 saturation of 75% on room air. He is stuporous, and pupils are pinpoint. He is subsequently given naloxone. Repeat vital signs are temperature of 36°C (96.8°F), pulse of 72/min, blood pressure of 107/71 mmHg and respiratory rate of 14/min, and O2 saturation of 95% on room air. The patient remains stuporous following administration of this medication. The patient is subsequently intubated and admitted to the intensive care unit, and an MRI of the head reveals the following image:


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia  

Which of the following is the most likely etiology of this patient’s clinical condition?

choices.text: Thrombi originating in the left atrium

questions.solution:
Hypoxic stroke, aka hypoxic ischemic encephalopathy, or global cerebral ischemia, develops in the setting of systemic hypoperfusion or hypoxemia. This type of stroke commonly occurs during cardiac arrest, shock states, prolonged hypoventilation due to drug overdose, drowning, or during invasive procedures with significant blood loss. The pattern of injury observed with this type of stroke often includes watershed infarctions, since the areas of the brain most susceptible to ischemic injury exist at the border of blood supply between two separate cerebral arteries. As blood flows through the vessels of the brain, tissue proximal to the circulation extracts oxygen and nutrients from the blood, leaving little to no oxygen or nutrients for tissue most distal to large collateral vascular supplies. As a result, these “watershed areas'' become ischemic, with subsequent tissue damage.  The three primary watershed areas include:

  •  The area between the anterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries 
  •  The area between the posterior cerebral and the middle cerebral arteries 
  •  The area between the external and internal branches of the middle cerebral arteries 
MRI imaging following a watershed infarction typically reveals a linear rosary-like pattern at the aforementioned anatomic locations. This patient’s MRI demonstrates multiple left subcortical infractions located at the border zone of MCA/ACA and MCA/PCA.


Reproduced from: Radiopaedia

Option Analysis

❌ Middle meningeal artery tear:
Incorrect: Trauma to the middle meningeal artery may cause an epidural hematoma. Patients with epidural hematomas present with loss of consciousness following head trauma, with a lucid interval, followed by progressive decline in mental status. Head imaging typically reveals a biconvex, hyperdense lesion.
✅ Prolonged cerebral hypoperfusion:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Rupture of bridging veins:
Incorrect: Rupture of  bridging veins refers to the etiology of subdural hematomas, which is more commonly observed in patients with fragile vasculature (e.g., infants, elderly patients). Head imaging demonstrates crescent-shaped, concave hemorrhages.
❌ Small-vessel lipohyalinosis:
Incorrect: Lacunar strokes are commonly precipitated by conditions causing arterial damage (e.g., hypertension, diabetes). This young patient is unlikely to have suffered a lacunar stroke, as his brain imaging suggests a different etiology.
❌ Thrombi originating in the left atrium:
Incorrect: Embolic strokes often occur in the setting of uncontrolled atrial fibrillation with rapid ventricular response. This patient’s pulse is regular.

questions.text:
A 63-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department because of her altered mental status, which began three hours ago. The patient is oriented only to herself. Medical history is notable for atrial fibrillation, type II diabetes mellitus, HIV infection, and recently-diagnosed histoplasmosis pneumonia. Her medications include warfarin, propranolol, metformin, and itraconazole. She declined antiretroviral treatment in the past. On arrival, the patient’s temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), blood pressure is 137/82 mmHg, and pulse is 78/min. Physical examination reveals 5/5 strength in all extremities. However, the patient cannot complete finger-to-nose testing or rapidly alternating movements. She attempts to get up but loses balance and falls back into the stretcher. CT head is shown below. Her INR is 7.2, blood glucose is 175 mg/dL, and her HbA1c is 9.2%. Which of the following best explains this patient’s presentation?  


Image reproduced from Radiopedia
questions.solution:
This patient presents with altered mental status and an inability to perform coordinated movements. Her CT scan confirms the presence of a hemorrhagic stroke, which likely occurred since the patient was concurrently taking warfarin and fluconazole without dose adjustments.  

Fluconazole, and other azoles, treat mycotic infections by inhibiting fungal 14-alpha-demethylase (a cytochrome p450 enzyme). Inhibition of this enzyme blocks ergosterol synthesis, which is a vital component of fungal cell membranes.     

Unfortunately, azoles can also inhibit human cytochrome p450 found in the liver. As a result, azoles can inhibit the breakdown and cause the overaccumulation of medications (e.g., warfarin, phenytoin, simvastatin) metabolized by hepatic cytochrome p450. Elevated plasma warfarin levels would manifest with an elevated INR, as in this patient's case, as well as increased risk for bleeding and hemorrhagic stroke.  

Option Analysis

❌ Accelerated formation of atherosclerotic lesions:
Incorrect: Poorly controlled diabetes mellitus can lead to the accelerated formation of atherosclerotic plaques within blood vessels, predisposing patients to ischemic stroke. However, the hyperdense lesion on the CT scan suggests a hemorrhagic stroke. Furthermore, the elevated INR raises concerns about a different cause of the patient’s stroke.  
✅ Impaired hepatic drug metabolism:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Enlargement of intracranial mass:
Incorrect: An intracranial mass (e.g. tumor) in the cerebellum can cause impaired coordination. This deficit may manifest as an inability to perform tasks that require coordination on physical examination. However, intracranial masses are more likely to cause gradual, rather than abrupt, the onset of neurological symptoms.   
❌ Embolic occlusion of intracranial vessels:
Incorrect: This patient has a history of atrial fibrillation, which can lead to thrombus formation within the left atrium. If parts of the thrombus break off and travel to the brain, the patient can develop an embolic ischemic stroke. However, this patient’s CT findings are more concerning for a hemorrhagic stroke.  
❌ Noncompliance with medical therapy:
Incorrect: Medical noncompliance, such as taking more warfarin than prescribed, can cause an elevated INR and predispose individuals to hemorrhagic stroke. However, this patient is taking warfarin concurrently with fluconazole. The latter blocks cytochrome p450, thereby inhibiting hepatic drug metabolism, and would account for the elevated INR.

questions.text: A 65-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her son because of a right-sided weakness that started an hour ago. According to the patient’s son, his mother initially experienced dizziness and developed right arm and leg weakness shortly afterward. Past medical history is significant for hypertension and type II diabetes mellitus. Current medications include aspirin and amlodipine. Temperature is 36.1°C (97.0°F), pulse is 85/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 190/110 mmHg. Physical examination shows a minimally responsive patient with 0/5 strength in the right upper and lower extremities. CT scan head shows left-sided intracerebral hemorrhage with a 4 mm midline shift towards the right. The patient is started on a mannitol infusion. She is most likely to develop which of the following electrolyte abnormalities?
questions.solution:
This patient received a mannitol infusion for management of elevated intracranial pressure. Mannitol works by rapidly increasing the plasma or tubular fluid osmolality, causing water to move from the intracellular space into the vascular space or tubular lumen. As the water is excreted, hypernatremia may follow. Water movement from the intracellular space to the extracellular space may cause hyponatremia and pulmonary edema. Additional side effects of mannitol therapy include headache, nausea, and vomiting.  



Option Analysis

❌ Hypokalemia:
Incorrect: Hypokalemia is an adverse effect associated with a loop or thiazide diuretics. Osmotic diuretics do not affect potassium excretion.  
❌ Hypocalciuria:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule, thereby decreasing calcium excretion in the urine. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
✅ Hypernatremia:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Hypercalcemia:
Incorrect: Thiazide diuretics increase calcium reabsorption at the distal convoluted tubule and can lead to hypercalcemia. Mannitol does not affect urinary calcium excretion.  
❌ Hyperkalemia:
Incorrect: This patient was started on mannitol to decrease intracranial pressure. Mannitol does not affect potassium excretion and would not cause hyperkalemia.

questions.text: A 25-year-old right-handed man is brought to the clinic by his parent for evaluation of "abnormal behavior.” The patient’s parent reports that the patient has been eating uncontrollably. The patient has also demonstrated inappropriate sexual behavior towards family members. Also of concern to the patient’s parent is that the patient seemed indifferent to the news that the patient’s other parent had passed away a few weeks ago. The patient’s parent denies any recent head trauma sustained by the patient but does state that the patient was hospitalized two months ago for a “brain infection.” A follow-up MRI is ordered. Which of the following parts of the brain is most likely to demonstrate abnormal findings?

choices.text: Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
Kluver-Bucy syndrome is a neurobehavioral syndrome that results from bilateral damage to the amygdala. It is characterized by three types of disinhibited behavior: increased sexual drive (hypersexuality), uncontrollable desire to eat (hyperphagia), and an urge for exploring objects by mouth (hyperorality). Lack of emotional responsiveness, recurrent unprovoked seizures, and visual agnosia (inability to recognize objects) are other symptoms that are also seen in Kluver-Bucy syndrome.  

The most common etiology of Kluver-Bucy syndrome is viral encephalitis typically caused by herpes simplex virus type 1, which can damage the temporal lobes and the amygdala. The amygdaloid nuclei are located within the temporal lobes and supplied by the anterior choroidal arteries. They comprise a portion of the the limbic system, which is responsible for sexual drive as well as emotional and behavioral responses. Other causes of Kluver-Bucy syndrome include temporal lobe surgery and head trauma that results in temporal lobe contusions.  



Option Analysis

❌ Angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere:
Incorrect: Gerstmann syndrome typically results from ischemic injury to the angular gyrus within the parietal lobe of the dominant hemisphere. Symptoms include finger agnosia, left-right disorientation, acalculia, agraphia, and alexia.
❌ Right subthalamic nucleus:
Incorrect: Injury to the right subthalamic nucleus could present with left-sided hemiballismus. Hemiballismus is an involuntary, large amplitude, unilateral movement of the limbs and most commonly results from a lacunar infarct sustained to the subthalamic nuclei.
❌ Hippocampus:
Incorrect: The primary role of the hippocampus includes the formation and retrieval of recent memories. Damage to this area results in anterograde amnesia.
❌ Inferior right parietal lobe:
Incorrect: Hemispatial neglect syndrome results from a lesion in the inferior parietal lobe of the non-dominant hemisphere. Clinical features associated with this syndrome include spatial neglect of the contralateral side of the body. Examples include construction apraxia (when asked to draw a clock, the individual only draws the right half of the clock), and dressing apraxia (the individual only dresses half of their body).
✅ Bilateral amygdala:
Correct: See Main Explanation.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department due to altered mental status and headaches for the past day. His roommate states that he was in his usual state until yesterday, when he started complaining of headaches, fever, and abnormal behavior. Temperature is 38.5°C (101.3°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 124/80 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is lethargic but arousable. The neck is supple with full range of motion. The patient responds to questions, but the speech is incomprehensible. Hyperreflexia is present. MRI of the head shows edema and hyperintensities in the temporal lobes. Which of the following is the most likely explanation for these findings?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with nonspecific symptoms such as fever and headache, which raises concern for a central nervous system (CNS) infection. The presence of altered mentation and incomprehensible speech imply the involvement of the brain parenchyma and favors the diagnosis of encephalitis.   

Encephalitis refers to the inflammation of the brain parenchyma that leads to neurologic dysfunction, including altered mental status (behavior or personality), motor or sensory deficits, and speech or movement disorders. Encephalitis may be caused by viruses, bacteria, parasites, autoimmune conditions, etc. Abnormal brain function helps to distinguish encephalitis from meningitis. Additionally, imaging (specifically an MRI) can help determine specific etiologies; this patient’s MRI shows temporal lobe irregularities, suggesting herpes simplex encephalitis as the potential diagnosis.  

Option Analysis

❌ Meningitis :
Incorrect: Meningitis refers to inflammation of the brain meninges, which manifests by cerebrospinal fluid pleocytosis. Meningitis typically presents with meningeal signs (e.g., nuchal rigidity, positive Brudzinski sign); additionally, the presence of altered mentation in this case favors another diagnosis. 
❌ Aseptic meningitis:
Incorrect: Aseptic meningitis refers to patients who present with clinical signs and laboratory evidence of meningeal inflammation but have negative routine bacterial cultures. The most common cause of aseptic meningitis is the enteroviruses family. Meningitis typically presents with meningeal signs (e.g., nuchal rigidity, positive Brudzinski sign); additionally, the presence of altered mentation in this case favors another diagnosis.  
❌ Brain abscess:
Incorrect: A brain abscess is a collection of pus within the brain parenchyma which can occur from direct spread of infection or from bacteremia, trauma, or surgery. Classic presentation may include headache, fever, and focal neurologic deficits. However, the head MRI showing temporal lobe irregularities in this case favors another diagnosis. 
✅ Encephalitis:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Myelitis :
Incorrect: Myelitis refers to the inflammation of the spinal cord, which may manifest as weakness, bladder dysfunction, flaccid paralysis, and weak/absent reflexes. This patient’s presentation favors another diagnosis.

questions.text: A 47-year-old male presents to his primary care physician with worsening gait disturbance. He says, “I feel so unsteady on my feet, I can only get around in a wheelchair now.” In addition, the patient has experienced severe lancinating pain in his back. Past medical history is notable for HIV, hypertension, type II diabetes mellitus, and polysubstance abuse. His temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 94/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 100/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 95% on room air. Neurological exam is notable for bilateral dysmetria, a positive Romberg sign, and absent deep tendon reflexes. A screening rapid plasma reagin (RPR) test is positive. Which of the following additional neurologic findings is commonly associated with this patient's condition?

choices.text: Loss of pain and temperature sensation

questions.solution:
This patient presents with a positive Romberg sign, dysmetria, and absent deep tendon reflexes, which are concerning for degenerative changes affecting the dorsal column of the spinal cord. Given his positive RPR test, the most likely etiology is tabes dorsalis secondary to a tertiary syphilis infection.  

Tabes dorsalis arises due to infection of the central nervous system (CNS) by Treponema pallidum, the spirochete that causes syphilis. The condition takes nearly 20 years to develop after initial infection. Infection of the spinal cord leads to demyelination and degeneration of the dorsal column and roots, resulting in findings of gait ataxia and incoordination.  

The most specific finding for tabes dorsalis is the Argyll-Robertson pupil, which is characterized by small bilateral pupils that do not constrict when exposed to bright light, but do constrict when focused on a nearby object. This finding is also termed light-near dissociation. Other common symptoms include lancinating pains, neurogenic urinary incontinence, and signs of dementia. Treatment involves administering intravenous penicillin.


Option Analysis

✅ Pupils that display light-near dissociation:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Relative afferent pupillary defect:
Incorrect: Marcus Gunn pupil (MGP) refers to a finding observed during the swinging-flashlight test. Normally, after exposure to bright light, a pupil constricts. A MGP, on the other hand, has a relative afferent pupillary defect. As a result, when light is rapidly transferred from the normal eye to the eye with MGP, the MGP dilates instead of constricting. However, MGP is not typically associated with tertiary syphilis. 
❌ Cranial nerve III palsy:
Incorrect: Cranial nerve (CN) III nerve palsy refers to a “down and out pupil,” wherein the pupil is enlarged and shifted inferolaterally. Etiologies include uncal herniation and microvascular disease. In contrast, this patient has a positive Romberg sign, dysmetria, and absent deep tendon reflexes, which is more consistent with neurosyphilis. Neurosyphillis would not typically cause a CN III palsy. 
❌ Loss of pain and temperature sensation:
Incorrect: Tabes dorsalis rarely affects the spinothalamic tract, which is an afferent pathway in the anterior spinal cord that relays pain and temperature sensation. This portion of the spinal cord is more commonly implicated in anterior spinal artery infarction or Brown-Sequard syndrome.  
❌ Saddle anesthesia:
Incorrect: Saddle anesthesia refers to numbness of the perineum and is often implicated in cauda equina syndrome. However, this patient lacks other findings that are worrisome for cauda equina syndrome, such as bowel/bladder incontinence or pain radiating down the legs.

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department by her partner due to high fever and severe headache accompanied by nausea and vomiting. The partner reported that the patient was fine until 2 days ago, when she started complaining of a headache and rapidly became confused. Temperature is 38.9°C (102°F), pulse is 80/min, respirations are 20/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is obtunded and responds only to noxious stimuli. Pupils are equal and responsive to light. When the neck is flexed, the patient flexes the lower limbs. A thorough skin examination reveals no rashes, petechiae, or purpura. CSF analysis shows elevated WBC count with polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, high protein, and numerous RBCs. A wet mount is performed and reveals the following:  


Retrieved from: Wikimedia Commons    
Further review of this patient's history will most likely reveal which of the following?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with rapidly progressive headaches, fever, and altered mental status. The physical examination shows nuchal rigidity, while the cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) results imply bacterial meningitis with numerous RBCs. Finally, the wet mount test of the CSF reveals motile trophozoites, favoring the diagnosis of primary amebic meningoencephalitis (PAM) caused by Naegleria fowleri.   

Naegleria fowleri is a protozoan parasite that can be found in fresh water sources worldwide. The most common risk factor for infection is recreational water activities. Trophozoites from the water penetrate the olfactory mucosa, cross the cribriform plates, and eventually reach the olfactory bulb and brain. PAM is an acute hemorrhagic meningoencephalitis with an extremely high mortality rate. Patients often present with high fevers, severe headache, photophobia, nausea, vomiting, behavioral changes, seizures, and altered mental status. Smell and taste abnormalities may occur early and imply the migration of the parasite through the olfactory mucosa. Eventually, severe intracranial hypertension develops, leading to herniation and death within days. CSF analysis typically shows high WBC count with marked polymorphonuclear predominance, low glucose, elevated protein, numerous RBCs (due to hemorrhage) but negative routine bacterial cultures and gram stain. Diagnosis is based upon the clinical suspicion and is established by observation of motile trophozoites on CSF wet mount. Conventional treatment includes amphotericin B as well as other agents.   

Option Analysis

❌ Hiking in the woods:
Incorrect: Lyme disease is caused by the bacteria Borrelia burgdorferi, transmitted via the Ixodes deer tick. Neurologic involvement typically occurs later in the course, though lymphocytic meningitis or encephalomyelitis can present in early disseminated Lyme disease. However, Lyme disease is diagnosed through serology (e.g., Western blot), rather than a wet mount. 
✅ Swimming in freshwater:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Recent travel to Africa :
Incorrect: Malaria is a mosquito-borne disease caused by a parasite that is endemic to central Africa. Patients with malaria typically present with fever, chills, headache, anemia, splenomegaly and flu-like illness. Malaria is diagnosed by viewing the parasite on thick blood smears, rather than a wet mount. 
❌ Army service:
Incorrect: Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is a gram-negative diplococci and is the second most common cause of meningitis in adults below the age of 60 years. Infections typically occur in the settings of weakened immunity or crowded areas with infected patients (army recruits). Diagnosis is made via culture-based tests or PCR, rather than a wet mount.
❌ Ingestion of uncooked food:
Incorrect: Cysticercosis is a parasitic infection caused by larval cysts of the cestode (tapeworm) Taenia solium. Humans acquire the larvae encysted in undercooked pork (intestinal larvae) and later pass the eggs in food contaminated with human feces (cysticercosis). Patients with disseminated disease present with multiple cystic CNS lesions and seizures. Diagnosis is made through serology and imaging, rather than a wet mount.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man is brought to the emergency department by family for evaluation of muscle pain. The patient is a construction worker and stepped on a rusty nail two weeks ago. The patient did not seek medical care after the incident. A few days ago, the patient noticed painful muscle spasms and difficulty with mouth opening. Temperature is 37.5 °C (99.5 °F), blood pressure is 137/73 mmHg, pulse is 70/min and respirations are 12/min. On physical examination, the patient is unable to open his jaw, and facial expression appears fixed. There is also backwards arching of the neck and head. A deep purulent wound is observed on the sole of the right foot. Which of the following best describes the mechanism of action of the toxin responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

choices.text: Inhibition of glycine and GABA release into the neuromuscular junction
Reduction of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles
Progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons

questions.solution:
This patient presents with painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backward arching of the head, and neck (opisthotonos) after stepping on a rusty nail. These symptoms are concerning for tetanus, which is caused by the bacterium Clostridium tetani (C. tetani).

C. tetani is an anaerobic Gram-positive bacterium that is ubiquitously present in the soil. Injuries such as deep puncture wounds or crush injuries can enable bacterial spores to enter the body. Afterward, the bacteria are able to proliferate under anaerobic conditions and produce neurotoxins that reach the central nervous system via retrograde axonal transport. The neurotoxins cleave SNARE proteins and block vesicles containing the inhibitory neurotransmitters glycine and gamma-aminobutyric acid (GABA) from being released into the neuromuscular junction. The end result is muscle overactivation and development of muscle spasms.

Symptoms of C. tetani infection (tetanus) include lockjaw, risus sardonicus (persistent smile-like expression due to facial muscle contractions), and opisthotonos (hyperextension of the neck and/or back). In more advanced stages, patients can develop autonomic dysfunction and eventually respiratory arrest (due to diaphragm failure).  

Option Analysis

❌ Stimulation of actin depolymerization:
Incorrect: Toxins produced by Clostridioides (formerly Clostridium) difficile can enter cells lining the intestinal walls and cause actin depolymerization, thereby increasing epithelial cell permeability and inducing apoptosis. C. difficile infection causes watery diarrhea, not the neuromuscular symptoms seen in this patient.  
❌ Inhibition of elongation factor 2:
Incorrect: The toxin produced by Corynebacterium diphtheriae inhibits elongation factor 2 (EF-2), leading to the formation of pseudomembranes in the oropharynx. In contrast, this patient has painful muscle spasms, lockjaw, as well as backwards arching of the head, and neck.  
✅ Inhibition of glycine and GABA release into the neuromuscular junction:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Reduction of acetylcholine release from intracellular vesicles:
Incorrect: Clostridium botulinum produces a toxin that prevents intracellular vesicles containing acetylcholine from fusing with the cellular membrane, thus preventing acetylcholine release into the neuromuscular junction. Botulism would cause flaccid paralysis, not spastic paralysis.  
❌ Progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons:
Incorrect: Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is characterized by progressive destruction of upper and lower motor neurons. The condition typically affects individuals in their 50-60s. In contrast, this patient has spastic symptoms after stepping on a rusty nail, which is more concerning for tetanus.

questions.text:
A 24-year-old male college student is brought to the emergency department by his roommate due to confusion and altered mental status. His roommate says that the patient was in his usual state until 2 days ago, when he started complaining of headaches and fatigue. Temperature is 39.0°C (102.2°F), pulse is 100/min, and blood pressure is 135/85 mmHg. On physical examination, the patient is disoriented, and nuchal rigidity is noted. Examination of the patient’s left leg is shown below, and similar lesions are seen on the contralateral leg and bilateral arms:  


Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons

Which of the following is the most likely point of entry of the pathogen responsible for this patient’s condition?
questions.solution:
This patient is presenting with headache, confusion, and fever, raising concerns for meningitis. The presence of risk factors (i.e. student dorms), along with petechial rash on the lower limbs, favors the diagnosis of Neisseria meningitidis infection.  

Neisseria meningitidis (meningococci) is a gram-negative diplococci that is capable of a variety of clinical manifestations ranging from transient fever and bacteremia to fulminant fatal disease within hours. The bacteria is transmitted through respiratory and oral secretions, whereby it attaches to the mucosal surfaces via pili (fimbriae) and colonizes the nasopharynx. In the nasopharynx, it produces IgA proteases that assist it to evade opsonization and destruction. Through the nasopharynx, the bacteria access the bloodstream, where it utilizes specialized proteins and enzymes to survive within neutrophils, neutralize complement activation and ultimately reach the brain.    

N. meningitidis can be found in the nasopharynx of healthy individuals; however, infection and bacteremia occur more commonly in crowded settings (e.g., dormitories, military barracks) and weakened immunity. Besides meningitis, other possible outcomes of infection include Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome (which presents as an acute adrenal insufficiency), disseminated intravascular coagulation, and shock. Diagnosis is made via culture-based tests or PCR. Treatment includes ceftriaxone or penicillin G. Prophylaxis with rifampin, ciprofloxacin, or ceftriaxone should be given immediately to all close contacts.  



Option Analysis

❌ Skin wound :
Incorrect: Traumatic skin injury can inoculate bloodstream infections from common pathogens found on the skin. These include bacteria such as Staphylococcus aureus or fungi like Candida albicans. Neisseria meningitidis does not spread through skin wounds. 
❌ Gastrointestinal tract:
Incorrect: Listeria monocytogenes can enter through the gastrointestinal tract; however, this usually occurs in immunocompromised patients or in the context of pregnancy, liver disease, alcoholism, and malignancy. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis. 
❌ Ear :
Incorrect: Haemophilus influenzae and Streptococcus pneumonia are a common cause of acute otitis media which can spread to the brain; however, this complication is very rare in developed countries. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis. 
✅ Nasopharynx:
Correct: See Main Explanation
❌ Lungs:
Incorrect: Streptococcus pneumonia can enter the blood through the lungs and result in bacteremia and meningitis. This patient’s presentation is consistent with another diagnosis.

questions.text:
A 19-year-old man comes to the emergency department with a severe headache, vomiting, and fever. The patient is a military recruit who is three weeks into bootcamp. His friend states that he appeared normal 12 hours ago. Temperature is 39.5 °C (103.1 °F), pulse is 120/min, respirations are 19/min, and blood pressure is 110/75 mmHg. The patient is markedly disoriented and unable to answer questions. Physical examination shows positive Kernig and Brudzinski signs. Serum glucose concentration is 90 mg/dL. A lumbar puncture is performed, and the cerebrospinal fluid gram stain is shown below:  

Reproduced from: Wikimedia Commons  

Cerebrospinal fluid analysis is most likely to reveal which of the following sets of findings?
questions.solution:
This young military recruit is presenting with a severe headache, vomiting, and high-grade fever. In addition, he has altered mental status and positive meningeal signs, which are all consistent with meningitis. Based on the patient’s risk factors, the most likely causative organism is Neisseria meningitidis, which is prevalent in crowded areas like military bases or college dorms, where it can spread quickly via respiratory droplets and oral secretions.  

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is often useful in differentiating the causes of meningitis. Normal CSF glucose concentration is approximately 75% of the serum glucose concentration. The CSF associated with fungal or bacterial meningitis tends to be <40% of blood glucose concentrations, as these microorganisms require glucose for survival and growth. The rapidly dividing bacteria also cause elevated protein and markedly high neutrophil predominant leukocytosis (polymorphonuclear). As opposed to bacterial etiologies, viral and tuberculous meningitis lead to lymphocyte predominant leukocytosis. Next, gram stain of the CSF can help identify the bacterial cause in order to direct the appropriate treatment. In the picture above, gram-negative diplococci can be seen within the neutrophils, which is characteristic of Neisseria meningitidis.  



Option Analysis

✅ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)110030015:
Correct: See Main Explanation.
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)806020:
Incorrect: This cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) analysis is consistent with Cryptococcus neoformans, Borrelia burgdorferi (Lyme disease), and Rickettsia meningitis, which tend to exhibit reduced glucose concentrations with a moderately increased lymphocyte count. 
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)704065:
Incorrect: This CSF analysis is consistent with viral meningitis, as characterized by a slightly elevated lymphocyte count, normal glucose, and normal protein levels. 
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)5050020:
Incorrect: This CSF analysis is consistent with tuberculosis (TB) meningitis, as characterized by slightly elevated lymphocyte count, markedly elevated protein level, and usually low glucose. Routine bacterial cultures would be negative.
❌ Cell count/mm3Protein level (mg/dL)Glucose level (mg/dL)43050:
Incorrect: This cerebrospinal fluid analysis is consistent with normal findings in a healthy person.

questions.text: A 65-year-old male comes to his primary care physician with worsening lower extremity weakness and fatigue. Over the past year, he has had increased difficulty climbing stairs and pain in his hips while doing so. Moreover, the patient has worsening fatigue, stating “I can only take a few steps before feeling short of breath.” He had an upper respiratory infection two weeks ago. Past medical history is notable for poliomyelitis as a child, hypertension, and asthma. Temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 67/min, respirations are 12/min, blood pressure is 112/74 mmHg, and O2 saturation is 98% on room air. Physical exam is notable for asymmetric bilateral lower extremity weakness and atrophy, left greater than right, as well as hypoactive patellar reflexes. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with a history of poliomyelitis presents with worsening asymmetric weakness, fatigue, and signs of lower motor neuron dysfunction (e.g., muscle atrophy, hyporeflexia). These findings are consistent with post-polio syndrome.   

Post-polio syndrome refers to new or progressively worsening muscle weakness in survivors of polio and typically manifests decades after the initial infection. The etiology of this syndrome remains unknown. Potential explanations include progressive degeneration of reinnervated motor units, persistence of poliovirus in neural tissue, or induction of autoimmune-mediated neural tissue destruction.  

Clinically, both polio and post-polio syndrome manifest with asymmetric weakness, hypotonia, flaccid paralysis, fasciculations, hyporeflexia, and muscle atrophy. Diagnosis of post-polio syndrome is based primarily on clinical findings, although recovery of the virus is attainable in some circumstances via lumbar puncture or stool samples. 

Option Analysis

✅ Post-polio syndrome:
Correct: See Main Explanation. 
❌ Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis:
Incorrect: Weakness is a common feature of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, but this disease tends to present with both signs of upper motor neuron (e.g., hyperreflexia, spasticity) and lower motor neuron (e.g., atrophy, fasciculations, hyporeflexia) disease. This patient has no clinical findings of an upper motor neuron lesion. 
❌ Guillain-Barre syndrome:
Incorrect: Guillain-Barre syndrome tends to present with symmetric, ascending, bilateral lower extremity weakness. In contrast, this patient has asymmetric weakness and a history of poliomyelitis, which is more concerning for post-polio syndrome. 
❌ Spinal muscular atrophy type 1 :
Incorrect: Werdnig-Hoffman disease, or infantile spinal muscular atrophy type 1, is an inherited lower motor neuron disease that results in degeneration of anterior horn cells. It usually presents between the ages of 6-12 months of life. 
❌  Polymyalgia rheumatica  :
Incorrect: Polymyalgia rheumatica refers to a rheumatologic condition characterized by pain and stiffness in the proximal musculature. It is not associated with muscle atrophy or reduced tendon reflexes.

questions.text: A 23-year-old gravida 1 para 0 woman presents to the obstetrics clinic to discuss pregnancy. Based on the first-trimester ultrasound, the patient is in the 20th week of gestation. As part of pregnancy complication counseling, the patient and physician discuss Listeria monocytogenes infection and how the risk of infection can be decreased. Which of the following measures can be taken to decrease the risk of infection with Listeria monocytogenes?

choices.text: Avoidance of handling cat litter boxes
Avoid contacts with infants with a rash
No measures can be taken to avoid infection with Listeria

questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is a Gram-positive bacterium. It is a food-borne pathogen that can be transmitted by unpasteurized dairy products or cold deli meat. The bacteria have the ability to survive and replicate in cold environments.

L. monocytogenes infection in healthy adults usually causes self-limited gastroenteritis. However, it can lead to severe infections in pregnant women, both in the mother and fetus. In pregnant women, L. monocytogenes can cause fever, gastrointestinal manifestations (e.g., vomiting, diarrhea), or a disseminated infection. If the bacteria crosses the placenta to the fetus, they can lead to catastrophic events, including stillbirth or miscarriage, or neonatal listeriosis.

Neonatal listeriosis can present with fever, respiratory distress, and granulomatosis infantiseptica which presents as a nodular rash and other symptoms. It can also cause meningitis, sepsis, and death in neonates.

Because of these severe complications, pregnant women should avoid cold deli meats and unpasteurized dairy products.  


Option Analysis

✅ Avoidance of cold deli meat:
Correct: See Main Explanation.  
❌ Avoidance of handling cat litter boxes:
Incorrect: Toxoplasmosis can lead to devastating infections for fetuses. Avoidance of cat feces should be done to prevent infection with Toxoplasma gondii.  
❌ Avoid contacts with infants with a rash:
